awd_titl_txt: Educating Robot Maintenance and Repair Technicians to Address Workforce Gaps in Automation and Skilled Trades
awd_abstract_narration:
As technological advances increase the demand for skilled workers in automation maintenance, local community colleges must educate and up-skill the technicians needed to keep local industries productive and competitive. This project will upgrade the automation program at Montcalm Community College to include robot maintenance and repair. Robot maintenance and repair technicians need the skills to maintain, correct, and repair robots so that automation operations can run efficiently and safely. In many cases, when a robot faults, it needs a human to correct its program and repair any damage. The ability of human technicians to troubleshoot and solve operation errors in robots keeps manufacturing processes running smoothly. The project will recruit new high school graduates and incumbent workers into the robot repair and maintenance field. It will provide these future technicians with hands-on learning experiences that build both the knowledge and skills that are needed for robot maintenance and repair. Professional development will be provided to enable current skilled trades faculty to learn to use new equipment and to earn relevant industry-validated credentials or certifications. Through interactions with local industry, the College will help employers find or educate workers to meet their robot maintenance and repair needs.   The project includes a mobile advanced technology learning facility that is housed in a trailer.  The trailer can be deployed at distant locations, enabling the College to meet robot maintenance/repair training needs of employers by bringing the classroom to the workplace. Project results and deliverables will be shared widely so successful practices can be adopted to meet growing demands for automation maintenance workers as robotics and automation expands.

This project aims to develop a state-of-the-art curriculum in robot maintenance and repair that addresses the needs of local businesses and provides students with a pathway from high school into the skilled technical workforce. The project will build curricula that span from entry level to advanced level, to enable multiple entry points into the education needed to work in automation maintenance. To accomplish these goals, the project will educate and up-skill faculty to teach robot maintenance and repair.  To better serve incumbent workers, the curriculum will be deliverable in a mobile advanced technology learning facility that can be deployed at workplaces.  In addition, the mobile learning facility will also be used to host hands-on activities involving robots at local workforce development offices and adult education schools, with the expectation of engaging about 200 adults. The mobile learning facility will also be used at outreach events at schools and other venues to engage students in robot repair/maintenance activities and illustrate the rewards of a career in automation and manufacturing. It is expected that the outreach efforts will reach as many as 800 high school students and generate increased enrollment in automation programs.  As a result, the project has the potential to increase the number of automation maintenance and related industrial workers who are available to fill more than 100 current openings in the local area.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Montcalm Community College (MCC) was awarded a National Science Foundation/Advanced Technology Education Grant to develop an innovative program in industrial automation maintenance to address an emerging industrial need. This program was designed to advance the College's industrial automation programming to meet the robot maintenance needs identified by local employers. The program was developed utilizing a ladder design where students begin with foundation courses before moving into robot maintenance-specific coursework. The first-year coursework was focused on basic industrial skills (applied mathematics, blueprint reading, industrial safety, etc.). This allowed a non-employed student to seek employment after the first year of the program. It also allowed students, who were unable to grasp automation skills, to apply the coursework to other related manufacturing careers. The work supported by the grant was scheduled to take place between July 1, 2019, and June 30, 2022. Extension was granted due to the impact of COVID until June 30, 2023. 


The following goals were developed to help local employers address training needs, increased community awareness, and interest in the robot maintenance field: 

Goal 1: Increase enrollment in industrial automation maintenance. 

As a result of the grant, faculty at MCC implemented a series of revisions to the Industrial Automation Maintenance Certificate and Industrial Automation Maintenance A.A.S. credit-bearing programs. The curriculum was reviewed by industry representatives and aligned with industry standards. Material no longer relevant to the career field was removed and replaced with updated information. Students now can earn industry credentials through the Smart Automation Certification Alliance (SACA). With this new alignment to industry credentials, the program now sees a year-to-year increase in the number of students enrolled in the automation programs. 

Goal 2: Provide professional development for faculty aimed at improving instructional practices and learning outcomes as well as obtainment of industry certifications. 

One of the main goals of this project was that faculty members would obtain FANUC, ABB, and KUKA maintenance certification along with industry-recognized automation/mechanics credentials. Faculty certifications were used as evidence of skills and knowledge to support the program. These certifications were reviewed with industry partners and revised to reflect the needs of companies in the area. KUKA was expanded to include three certifications; FANUC was expanded to eight certifications; and ABB certification was removed since these robots are rarely used. Additional certifications were added to meet the needs of the employers: Siemens, NIMS, and SACA. Faculty earning these certifications reflects the expertise gained through this grant.  

Goal 3: Develop and disseminate industrial automation curricula. 

The institution successfully developed and implemented a job training certificate that ladders into industrial automation maintenance certificate which in turn ladders into an Associates? degree that provides additional benefits to students. The second part of this goal was the dissemination of industrial automation curricula. The new automation curricula align with Smart Automation Certification Alliance (SACA) standards. Through SACA, our curriculum has visibility to partner institutions across the country. During COVID, three institutions contacted MCC to help align their courses with the SACA certifications. At ATE Principal Investigators Conferences the institution connected to others through ATE Connects and live/pre-recorded Spotlight Sessions. ATE Connects gave MCC the opportunity to network with others throughout the country. Through the Spotlight Sessions, industry partners shared their insights on trends and the value of skilled employees. 

Goal 4: Strengthen industry partnerships through collaboration in developing and reviewing industrial automation curriculum, labs, and student curriculum, and hands-on skills for the trailer.  

The work continues with local industry partners to monitor the value of the new curriculum through the skills they see in their employees. Their feedback is part of the Advisory Committee discussions. As part of the college partnership, an employee of one of the local companies volunteered to help develop the curriculum for the recruiting workshops.  

Challenges and solutions: Data is worthless unless it is turned into information and used to make improvements. COVID caused many problems, including how to collect the necessary data and the reliability and validity of the data that was collected. Assessment and quality improvement is difficult enough during ?normal? times (normal = non-COVID), but COVID made it virtually impossible. Data was collected, but due to the required changes to delivery and assessment techniques, the data could not be aggregated and applied to future students. That being said, we were able to refine the assessment tools and techniques for future assessment purposes. Aligning the curriculum to the Smart Automation Certification Alliance (SACA) has allowed MCC to share the curriculum with other institutions and to use SACA assessments to validate the knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) that students possess. Although this may seem trivial, it is a tremendous accomplishment. Students will gain a third-party credential and MCC can compare student performance to other students throughout the world.
